questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with intensely itchy vesicular skin lesions on elbows and knees. Her mother says that she is giving him rice based diet only and he does not tolerate cereals. Skin biopsy was performed from the lesions and IF staining is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Dermatitis herpetiformis

  • The patient's intolerance to cereals (gluten-containing foods) and rice-based diet suggests an underlying gluten sensitivity, which is typical of dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic autoimmune blistering skin condition associated with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease. It presents as intensely pruritic, grouped vesicles and papules predominantly on extensor surfaces such as elbows and knees.
  • Immunofluorescence staining shows granular/ focal IgA deposits in dermal papillae.
  • Option A has bullous lesion with linear IgG deposits instead of focal granular deposits seen here. 
  • Option B has Fish net appearance on IF due to damage to desmosomes
  • Option D presents with mica like scales with characterstic bleeding on removal of scales

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about celiac sprue?

choices.text: Demonstration of host genetic factors HLA DQ2 DQ8 is a must for diagnosis
BROW cereals intake is mainstay of managing the disease
Leading cause is colonization of gut by Tropheryma whippelli

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Presents with iron deficiency anaemia

  • Celiac sprue presentation can range from malabsorption of multiple nutrients to iron deficiency due to duodenal disease.
  • Detection of alleles for HLADQ2 and DQ8 is not useful for diagnosis. They can be found in 25–35% of the general population who do because most carriers. In contrast negative test is very useful for ruling out celiac disease, with a negative predictive value of >99%.
  • Option B is wrong as BROW cereals must be restricted. Option D is for Whipple’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about celiac sprue?

choices.text: Lipid laden intestinal epithelial cells that appears normal after 72 hours fasting

questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Lipid laden intestinal epithelial cells that appears normal after 72 hours fasting

  • Lipid laden intestinal epithelial cells that appears normal after 72 hours fasting is seen in abetalipoproteinemia and not celiac sprue
  • Celiac sprue can cause crypt hyperplasia and fluid hypersecretion from crypt epithelium.
  • Villous atrophy can explain steatorrhea and lactase deficiency.

questions.text: Middle aged man presented with arthralgias, diarrhoea, weight loss and abdominal pain. Small intestinal mucosal biopsy shows PAS positive macrophages laden with intracellular bacteria. Which of the following is correct about management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Ceftriaxone plus oral TMP-SMX

  • Key word is PAS positive intracellular bacteria that helps in diagnosis as Whipple’s disease. Treatment of choice for Whipple disease is Ceftriaxone plus oral TMP-SMX.

questions.text: Severity of celiac sprue is determined by which classification?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Marsh

  • The severity of celiac sprue is determined by the Marsh classification. It grades the histological changes in the small intestinal mucosa from type 0 (normal mucosa) to type 4 (total architectural atrophy). Parameters are-
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Villous atrophy
    • Degree of intraepithelial lymphocytosis
  • Forrest classification is used for assessment of patient with GI bleeding due to peptic ulcers
  • Vienna and Montreal classifications are related to inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) classifications.
  • Truelove and Witts classification is for severity of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: 30-year-old woman with scleroderma was having steatorrhea and anaemia. She was found to have vitamin B12 deficiency and elevated serum folate levels. Which of the following is probable cause of her malabsorptive diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth

  • Scleroderma leads to stasis of bowel contents leading to small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. This damages ileal mucosa. The Key words are low vitamin B12 levels implying involvement of terminal ileum. SIBO has elevated folate levels derived from bacterial synthesis of folate.

questions.text: 30-year-old woman with scleroderma was having steatorrhea and anaemia. She was found to have vitamin B12 deficiency and elevated serum folate levels. Which is next best investigation to be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Duodenal aspirate for bacterial titers

  • Scleroderma leads to stasis of bowel contents leading to small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. This damages the ileal mucosa. The key words are low vitamin B12 levels implying involvement of terminal ileum. SIBO has elevated folate levels derived from bacterial synthesis of folate. Gold standard investigation for this case is duodenal aspirate for bacterial cultures. It may not be available routinely. So, breath hydrogen test can be done but must be interpreted with caution. Else empirical antibiotic therapy can be given and response evaluated.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct treatment of tropical sprue?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Tetracycline with folic acid

  • The exact organism causing tropical sprue is not known. However broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracycline have been found to be useful. Folic acid is absorbed from duodenum and proximal jejunum.

questions.text: Stool alpha1 anti-trypsin levels are used for diagnosis of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Protein losing enteropathy

  • Alpha 1 antitrypsin accounts for 4% of total serum proteins and is resistant to proteolysis. When there is excessive protein loss through the gastrointestinal tract, alpha1 antitrypsin leaks into the intestines and appears in the stool and if elevated is diagnostic of protein losing enteropathy

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency: This is a genetic disorder causing deficient or dysfunctional alpha1 antitrypsin protein causing cirrhosis with pan-acinar emphysema. Diagnosis is based on serum levels, phenotype, and genetic testing.

Option C - Small bowel syndrome: Occurs due to extensive removal of small intestine resulting in <200 cm remaining.

Option D - Abetalipoproteinemia: This is a rare inherited disorder of fat absorption caused by defective lipoprotein production. Diagnosis relies on clinical features like acanthocytosis, lipid profile abnormalities, and genetics

questions.text: You are asked to evaluate lab reports of patient with peripheral oedema. Serum albumin is low and serum globulin is low. Which of the following is likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Protein losing enteropathy

  • Cirrhosis will have low albumin due to less production but globulin is increased due to decreased clearance.
  • Minimal change disease has selective proteinuria leading to low albumin.
  • SCID will have low globulin but protein losing enteropathy has both low albumin and low globulin due to losses via GIT

questions.text: Gold standard investigation for steatorrhea is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: 72-hour faecal fat estimation

  • Steatorrhea is defined as stool fat excretion > 7% fat of dietary fat. Gold standard investigation for it is 72-hour faecal fat estimation.
  • Breath triolein test is a non-invasive screening method but not the gold standard; it’s less sensitive and rarely used in clinical practice.
  • PIVKA test measures abnormal prothrombin due to vitamin K deficiency, mainly used as a marker for liver cancer
  • Small intestinal mucosal biopsy is useful for identifying underlying mucosal diseases (like celiac disease) causing malabsorption, but it does not directly quantify fat loss.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not a cause of protein losing enteropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Abetalipoproteinemia

  • Ulcerative colitis (a) can cause protein losing enteropathy due to mucosal ulceration and inflammation leading to protein leakage into the gut.
  • Menetrier disease (b) is characterized by hypertrophic gastric folds and increased mucus production that rich in protein. 
  • Intestinal lymphangiectasia (c) causes PLE due to elevated pressure in the intestinal lymphatics is the driving factor that causes rupture/leakage of lymph that contains proteins. 
  • Abetalipoproteinemia (d) is a rare inherited disorder causing fat malabsorption and deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins and defective RBC called acanthocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following GI condition will have intestinal biopsy finding of normal villi with epithelial cells vacuolated with fat post prandially?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Abetalipoproteinemia

Option A has deficiency of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP).This defect causes failure to transport dietary fats, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) from the intestines and liver into the bloodstream.

Option B Agammaglobulinemia, there is a significant deficiency of immunoglobulins, including IgA, which compromises this protective mucosal immunity. As a result, patients are more susceptible to recurrent infections such as bloody diarrhoea and infectious gastroenteritis. Gut biopsy will have absence of plasma cells.

Option C has dilated lymphatics with clubbing of villi. Option D will have malignant cells in lamina propria and submucosa.
